ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the different biological reactions and pathways that can be exploited for environmental engineering. I also developed a framework for how to model and understand different engineered systems with biological processes. Lastly, I learned about technologies and current challenges faced in topics including wastewater treatment, methanogenesis, biofuels, and exposure assessments.
I learned about bioreactor design and biological mechanisms in built environmental systems.
Most engineering concepts were new to me, I learned a lot
I further solidified biological engineering principles, particularly in contaminant removal kinetics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths include covering a wide variety of topics and thinking outside the book, insightful class discussions with real-world examples, and carefully going through problem solving steps. Sometimes the material and problem solving felt too empirical (e.g., using empirically derived constants without thinking very much about what the variables mean or where the constants came from.
The assignments and tests are really fair and well designed based on the content of the course.
A field trip would have been a great thing to add

The information in the course is well-structured, and builds logically on itself. The homework assignments were generally fair, took a reasonable amount of time, and helped solidify the concepts. The book and supplementary readings were mostly very helpful (except for a few sections in the book that had minor errors in equations or used variable names that were not the ones we used in class). The exams were difficult, and genuinely took me the entire class time to do, but the information in them was reasonable to expect of us.

Overall, it's difficult to think of ways to improve the class. Perhaps different placement of TA office hours would be helpful, that were not so close to when previous homeworks were due would help. Maybe a more explicit in-class (or office hours) review session before each exam would be helpful, but that may just depend on the class's preference. There were also a few homework questions that were phrased a little confusingly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, there is a lot to learn from this class about the current state of environmental engineering, energy, and frameworks used to understand biological processes.
Yes, this is a really well taught course and very engaging, even if you're not interested in biological systems within the broader field of environmental engineering.
yes, this is a great course to learn a lot about the Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering

Yes, absolutely. This is a great course if you want to understand the basics of biological water treatment, and bacterial pollutant treatment more generally. This is exactly the course I'd recommend to anyone going into water treatment.
